The Inverse Exponential distribution

Source: R/dist_inverse_exponential.R
dist_inverse_exponential.Rd

dist_inverse_exponential(rate)

Arguments

rate

an alternative way to specify the scale.

See also

actuar::InverseExponential

Examples

dist <- dist_inverse_exponential(rate = 1:5)
dist
#> <distribution[5]>
#> [1] InvExp(1) InvExp(2) InvExp(3) InvExp(4) InvExp(5)

mean(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
variance(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
support(dist)
#> <support_region[5]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1]  1.8213379  0.8613413 36.8369565  9.6233694  2.2276399  5.4623900
#>  [7]  0.4319173  0.4965437 23.8784321  1.3790102
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1] 0.2058343 0.2316058 9.3544644 1.5266467 0.4476106 2.8323544 4.3569579
#>  [8] 3.9175360 0.6034050 0.2041194
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1] 0.1918217 5.0646288 3.5689354 0.1405498 0.6569086 0.3106100 0.2558391
#>  [8] 0.4069430 0.1079401 1.3176736
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 0.1025675 0.3862800 1.5576972 0.3861273 0.7509636 0.5422488 0.5219681
#>  [8] 1.0935386 1.3770224 0.4062396
#> 
#> [[5]]
#>  [1]   0.46400580   0.09443864   0.12975408   1.95167770   0.17059242
#>  [6]   0.04626913   0.37933962   0.02677750 225.76643552   1.92177042
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 0.15163266 0.09735010 0.07054014 0.05515606 0.04524187
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -1.886294 -2.329442 -2.651573 -2.897589 -3.095732

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.7788008 0.8824969 0.9200444 0.9394131 0.9512294

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 2.8036733 1.4018366 0.9345578 0.7009183 0.5607347
